events.title: Birth
events.summary: Léo Delibes was born in Saint-Germain-du-Val, now part of La Flèche, on 21 February 1836. He was the couple's only child, and his father worked for the French postal service while his mother was a talented amateur musician, the daughter of an opera singer.
events.fun_version: Léo Delibes was born in Saint-Germain-du-Val, now sneaking its way into La Flèche, on 21 February 1836. He was the couple's only child, and his father worked for the French postal service, while his mother, a talented amateur musician and daughter of an opera singer, fancied herself an opera singer—performing for the family cat and winning every time.

events.title: Father's Death
events.summary: Delibes' father died in 1847, leading the family to move to Paris. This change occurred when Delibes was just 11 years old.
events.fun_version: Delibes' father passed away in 1847, prompting the family to move to Paris when Delibes was just 11 years old. This relocating process took place when Delibes was a pre-teen, trying to navigate the city of lights while figuring out the chaos of growing up!

events.title: Paris Conservatoire Admission
events.summary: Shortly after his twelfth birthday, Delibes was admitted to the Paris Conservatoire, where he began his formal music education.
events.fun_version: After blowing out the candles on his twelfth birthday cake, Delibes waltzed his way into the Paris Conservatoire, where he began his formal music education!

events.title: First Stage Work Premiere
events.summary: In 1856, Léo Delibes' first stage work, Deux sous de charbon, premiered at the Folies-Nouvelles. It was a one-act comic piece and marked the beginning of his career as a composer.
events.fun_version: In 1856, Leo Delibes burst onto the stage with his first theatrical gem, "Deux sous de charbon". This one-act comic piece marked the beginning of his career as a composer at the Folies-Nouvelles.

events.title: Coppélia First Performance
events.summary: Delibes gained wider public recognition in 1870 with his score for the ballet Coppélia, first performed at the Opéra. The ballet was an immediate success and remains popular in the classical ballet repertoire.
events.fun_version: In 1870, Delibes hit the jackpot with his ballet score for Coppélia! This majestic performance at the Opéra was so well-received that it practically received a standing ovation before it even started. Not only did it gain wide recognition, but let’s be honest, it’s still waltzing around our hearts and keeping its spot in the classical ballet repertoire!

events.title: Return to Opéra with Sylvia
events.summary: In 1876, Delibes returned to the Opéra with his grand mythological ballet, Sylvia, which was well received by both the press and the public.
events.fun_version: In 1876, Delibes waltzed back into the Opéra with his grand ballet, Sylvia, which was so well received that even the chandeliers were applauding—though I'd recommend checking if any of them have had a few too many drinks!

events.title: Lakmé Premiere
events.summary: On 14 April 1883, Delibes' opera Lakmé premiered at the Opéra-Comique. The opera was known for its lavish staging and charming music.
events.fun_version: On 14 April 1883, the grand spectacle of Delibes' opera Lakmé premiered at the Opéra-Comique, where the music was so charming it could lull a caffeinated squirrel to sleep, and the staging was so lavish that it made even the Queen's tea parties feel like a picnic at the park!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Léo Delibes died at his home in Paris after a sudden collapse shortly before his 55th birthday. He had been intermittently ill for some time before his death.
events.fun_version: Léo Delibes decided to throw a surprise party for his 55th birthday but ended up being the ultimate party pooper. Sadly, he had been feeling under the weather intermittently before this dramatic exit.

works.title: Morceau à déchiffrer pour la trompette
Morceau à déchiffrer pour la harpe
Leçon à déchiffrer pour la contrebasse
Quand je la vis pour la première fois
Morceau à déchiffrer pour le trombone
